text: there are a whole bunch of operators that have "hacked in" curried calls, see `Base.Fix2`.  I say "hacked in" because someone actually had to define these methods by hand (or in a metaprogramming loop at least).  Would be way better if we could get generalized currying, but in the meantime, yeah these are really nice to have

.  I say "hacked in" because someone actually had to define these methods by hand (or in a metaprogramming loop at least).  Would be way better if we could get generalized currying, but in the meantime, yeah these are really nice to have

text: Generalizing currying would be nice... similar to the dot in dot broadcasting

elements.text: Generalizing currying would be nice... similar to the dot in dot broadcasting

text:
generalized currying is a massive can of worms.
Especially because all the manually curried rules we have have the second arguement fixed, not the first.
The first is what traditional currying would give you.

elements.text:
generalized currying is a massive can of worms.
Especially because all the manually curried rules we have have the second arguement fixed, not the first.
The first is what traditional currying would give you.

text:
but the second is the one that is useful for.
`<=` , `>=` , `startswith` , `endswith` and `contains`

(either is useful for `isequal` , `==` and `isapprox`)
